title: Force applied to a box initially at rest

content.question: A force <math alttext="F sub 0" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> is applied continuously to a box initially at rest on a horizontal surface. The box slides with negligible friction for equal distances <math alttext="d sub 1" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="d sub 2" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, as shown. How does the kinetic energy gained by the block over distance interval <math alttext="d sub 2" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="delta K sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mo>∆</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, compare to the kinetic energy gained over distance interval <math alttext="d sub 1" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="delta K sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mo>∆</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, and why?

choices.label: <math alttext="delta K sub 2 equals delta K sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mo>∆</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mo>∆</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, because the velocity increases by the same amount over intervals <math alttext="d sub 1" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="d sub 2" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>.

<math alttext="delta K sub 2 equals delta K sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mo>∆</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mo>∆</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, because the applied force does the same work on the block over intervals <math alttext="d sub 1" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="d sub 2" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>.

<math alttext="delta K sub 2 is greater than delta K sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mo>∆</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mo>∆</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, because the block is moving faster on average over interval <math alttext="d sub 2" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>.

<math alttext="delta K sub 2 is greater than delta K sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mo>∆</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mo>∆</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, because the rate of change of kinetic energy is greater over interval <math alttext="d sub 2" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>.

content.answer: <math alttext="delta K sub 2 equals delta K sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mo>∆</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mo>∆</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, because the applied force does the same work on the block over intervals <math alttext="d sub 1" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="d sub 2" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>.

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
